<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The Wagoner County Courthouse is closed because of the lack of water available in the city.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The Department of Environmental Quality has issued a boil order for any water that might come through water lines in Wagoner. People are advised not to drink the water.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Wagoner officials say a part that is necessary to get water production back on track may have to be fabricated.</p>
<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Potable water will be trucked into Wagoner on Monday and will be available at the First United Methodist Church, the Wagoner Civic Center, Wagoner Community Hospital and Rural Water District #6 on the west side of the city.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block visible-xs" id="tncms-block-1124943">
<!-- Mobile Rectangle ATF 300x250 article -->

AdBridg.cmd.push(function() { AdBridg.display('mobileRectangle_atf'); });
</script>
</div>
<div class="clear" style="padding-bottom:10px"></div>
</div></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">People need to bring containers for water.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#sticky-right-rail');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="sticky-right-rail-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#tncms-region-global-container-bottom') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#main-bottom-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>

<a class="h6 gray-dark-link text-capitalize block-display air-xxs" href="https://patch.com/rhode-island/middletown/politics">politics & government</a> <h1>
      Atlantic Beach Closed to Swimming    </h1>
<h2 class="h4">The Rhode Island Department of Health recommended closing Atlantic Beach Tuesday afternoon around 4 p.m.</h2> <div class="clearfix summary-additional">
<span class="h6">By <a href="https://patch.com/users/angela-lemire">Angela Lemire, <span class="text-neutral">Patch Staff</span> </a> | <time datetime="2011-06-28 20:18:36">Jun 28, 2011 8:18 pm ET</time> | Updated <time datetime="2011-06-28 20:47:24">Jun 28, 2011 8:47 pm ET</time><a class="edit-p soft-hide gray-subtle-link" href="https://my.patch.com/article/1666144/edit" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Moderate Content."><span class="separator"></span> <span aria-hidden="true" class="fal fa-paragraph fa-xs"></span></a></span><div class="flag-fb-like-wrapper air-xs-t"><div class="fb-like" data-action="like" data-href="https://patch.com/rhode-island/middletown/atlantic-beach-closed-to-swimming" data-layout="button_count" data-share="true"></div></div> </div>
</div>
</section> <!-- /.block -->
</div>
</header> <!-- /#page-header -->
<div class="row">
<section class="col-md-8">
<a id="main-content"></a>
<div class="region region-content">
<section class="block block-system clearfix" id="block-system-main">
<div class="article-page-default not-posted-today">
<section id="beginning-of-article"></section>
<div class="social-share-wrapper"><div class="social-share text-center"><a alt="Share on Facebook" category="social" class="social-btn social-btn-facebook" href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A//patch.com/rhode-island/middletown/atlantic-beach-closed-to-swimming" target="_blank" title="Share on Facebook" trigger="facebook"><span title="Send Email" trigger="email"><span class="fa fa-2x fa-envelope"></span></a><a class="btn-comment-now social-btn social-btn-comments" href="#comments" title="View Comments for “Atlantic Beach Closed to Swimming”"><span class="fa fa-2x fa-comments"></span><span class="disqus-comment-count p bold visible-lg-block visible-md-block visible-sm-block visible-xs-inline-block" data-disqus-identifier="1666144">0</span></a></div></div>
<div class="content-main-image">
<img alt="Atlantic Beach Closed to Swimming" class="img-responsive center-block" src="https://cdn.patchcdn.com/users/39080/2011/06/T800x600/35370493dc04eda3a6a641057ae206de.jpg"/> </div>
<div class="content-body center-block" id="article-wrapper">
<p>The Rhode Island Department of Health (DOH) recommended the temporary closure of Atlantic Beach Tuesday afternoon to swimming and other activities due to high bacteria levels in the water.</p> <p>The closure was the second this year for Atlantic Beach, according to the <a href="http://www.ribeaches.org/beach.cfm?beachID=RI673854" rel="nofollow">DOH website.</a></p> <p>The recommendation was made based on results from water samples that showed high bacteria levels<a href="http://www.ribeaches.org/closures.cfm" rel="nofollow"></a>. The health department will continue to monitor the water quality regularly to assure safe bathing throughout the summer season, officials stated in an announcement.</p> <p>Atlantic Beach typically experiences the most closures following heavy rains each summer. In 2010, the beach closed six times due to high bacteria levels. It closed eight times in 2009.</p> <p>The bacteria commonly found at Atlantic Beach is linked to fecal coliform often found in city sewage. Health risks associated with the bacteria often include gastrointestinal illness, such as nausea, vomiting and diarrhea, as well as infections to any open cuts or wounds. According to online medical journals, other links have been drawn to various infections such as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urinary_tract_infection" rel="nofollow">urinary tract infections</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteremia" rel="nofollow">bacteremia</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacterial_endocarditis" rel="nofollow">bacterial endocarditis</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diverticulitis" rel="nofollow">diverticulitis</a>, and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meningitis" rel="nofollow">meningitis</a>.</p> <h2>For more information</h2> <ul> <li>To check on the latest information regarding beach closings or advisories, call the Health Department Beach Hotline at 401-222-2751 or click <a href="http://www.ribeaches.org/closures.cfm" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</li> <li>about the efforts of Middletown and Newport to reduce stormwater pollutants into Easton's Bay. </li> </ul><div id="in-article-boxed-recirc"><div class="text-center air-md"><a category="subscribe" class="btn btn-lg btn-cta-alt pill sans in-article-subscribe l-bold" href="/" trigger="article_button_click">   Subscribe  <span aria-hidden="true" class="fal fa-angle-right fa-lg"></span></a></div></div> </div>

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> On Friday, a mandatory water boil advisory was set in place after  testing by the Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality in Hughes Country Rural Water District 2.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Meanwhile, a Pittsburg County resident has offered free water to Stuart livestock owners who have been unable to water their animals because of a water shortage.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The McAlester News-Capital received two emails Friday from District 17 State Rep. Brian Renegar, D-Blanco.</p>

</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">In an email to Renegar from Department of Environmental Quality Executive Deputy Director Jimmy Givens, the DEQ official said tests of water serving Stuart required a mandatory boil order.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">“I wanted to let you know that, based on the inspection and tests run by DEQ’s Water Quality Division today, we have concluded it is necessary to issue a mandatory water use advisory for Hughes County RWD 2.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">“While the pressure has remained relatively consistent since yesterday afternoon, the turbidity readings were high and the chlorine residual readings in the distribution system were low,” Givens told Renegar.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">“Because of the risk associated with these factors, DEQ believes that a mandatory notice to customers is necessary,” Givens said in an email to Renegar.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">“The RWD is obligated to tell customers that they need to boil their water or use an alternate supply (e.g. bottled water) for drinking and cooking. While many may already be doing so as a result of the earlier 'precautionary' advisory, this effectively ratchets up the force and should ensure even wider dissemination.”</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset, stf","fold":"span","include_domain":"cnhi\/mcalesternews","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/mcalesternews.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>

</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block visible-xs" id="tncms-block-1159022">

</div></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Meanwhile, Stuart livestock owners can contact Mike Thomas at 918-424-4709. He said he has plenty of well water he is offering Stuart residents for free. Earlier, the water district had told customers they could no longer water livestock due to the water shortage.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Contact MJ Brickey by email <a href="mailto:mjbrickey@journalist.com">mjbrickey@journalist.com</a>.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">For more on this story, see Sunday's print edition of the McAlester News-Capital.</p>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#sticky-right-rail');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="sticky-right-rail-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#tncms-region-global-container-bottom') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#main-bottom-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>
</div>

Boil Water Notice For Parts of Valencia Wood Neighborhood in Winter Haven

Monday
Jun 27, 2011 at 7:08 PM

The City of Winter Haven has issued a boil water notice for parts of the Valencia Wood neighborhood.

A total of 65 homes were impacted by emergency repairs to an 8-inch water line. The addresses were from 85 to 100 Lake Otis Road, 203 to 247 Polk Drive, 112 to 148 Lake Ring, 66 to 99 Alachua Drive, 334 to 340 Lake Marie Road, 201 to 300 Manatee Road, 20 to 50 Brevard Drive, and 210 to 252 Nassau Drive.

Residents in these areas are advised to bring water to a full, rolling boil for one minute if it will be used for drinking, cooking or washing vegetables and fruits.

A notice will be issued by the city when the boil water order is rescinded.
The cause of the damage to the water line was not available this evening.

Water main break in Scott City

SCOTT CITY, MO (KFVS) -

According to the Scott City Police Department, there was a water main break Saturday morning in Scott City.

It is at the corner of Broadway and Jefferson Streets.

Police say no boil water order is in effect at this time. They say the break should be fixed sometime today.

There is no word on what caused the break.

        Miller: 50 years</a></h3>
</div>
<div class="card-lead">
<p>PLATTSBURGH – Gerald (Richard) and Linda (Flint) Miller of Plattsburgh, N.Y. celebrated their 50<sup>th</sup> wedding anniversary on September 29<sup>th</sup>, 2017. Linda and Richard were married at St. Peter’s church, Plattsburgh, N.Y. on September 29<sup>th</sup>, 1967.</p>
</div>

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The New York State Department of Health has rescinded the boil-water order that has been in effect the past two months in the Town of Essex.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">An elated Town Supervisor Sharon Boisen said in an email that she was “relieved that Essex residents, business owners and visitors to the town will no longer have the added expense and inconvenience that a DOH boil-water order creates.”</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Eateries, such as Essex Provisions, were particularly hit hard.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">“When they asked for a glass of water and we had to turn them down, some customers from out of town thought we were doing this to sell water,” co-proprietor Stephanie Wilber related.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The boil-water edict was prompted by turbidity, which is the cloudiness or haziness of a fluid caused by individual particles (suspended solids) that are generally invisible to the naked eye, similar to smoke in air.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The measurement of turbidity is one of the tests of water quality.</p>
<p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Fluids can contain suspended solid matter consisting of particles of many different sizes. While some suspended material will be large enough and heavy enough to settle rapidly to the bottom of the container if a liquid sample is left to stand, very small particles will settle only very slowly or not at all if the sample is regularly agitated or the particles are colloidal, according to the Health Department.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Turbidity may be caused by high sediment levels entering water bodies, such as Lake Champlain, during rainstorms due to storm-water runoff and high bank erosion. This is what most likely happened in Essex, due to the heavy spring rains and subsequent flooding.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block visible-xs" id="tncms-block-1108091">
<!-- Mobile Rectangle ATF 300x250 article -->
<div class="visible-xs visible-sm" id="mobileRectangle_atf" style="width:100%;text-align:center">
<script type="text/javascript">
AdBridg.cmd.push(function() { AdBridg.display('mobileRectangle_atf'); });
</script>
</div>
<div class="clear" style="padding-bottom:10px"></div>
</div></div><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">In drinking water, the higher the turbidity level, the higher the risk that people may develop gastrointestinal diseases, since the particles may contain pathogens that are attached to the suspended solids.</p><p xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Those can interfere with attempts to purify the water with chlorine or ultraviolet light because the particles act as shields for the virus and bacteria.</p><p class="story_credit" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Email Alvin Reiner at: <a href="mailto:rondackrambler@yahoo.com">rondackrambler@yahoo.com</a></p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

            var $region = $('#sticky-right-rail');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="sticky-right-rail-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#tncms-region-global-container-bottom') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#main-bottom-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });

Boil-Water Order in Parts of Nassau County

E.coli contamination warning for Long Island.

    NEWSLETTERS

    Receive the latest local updates in your inbox

    Privacy policy | More Newsletters

    A boil-water order has been issued in parts of Nassau County where E. coli bacteria was found in water.

    Residents in North Valley Stream, Elmont, Franklin Square, Garden City, Stewart Manor, Floral Park, and New Hyde Park are being told to boil their water or to use bottled water.

    The contaminated water sample was collected near North Fletcher Avenue and Dutch Broadway on Monday, according to the Water Authority. Officials returned to the location the following day to test the water again and found it negative for E. coli; however, water collected nearby tested positive for Total Coliform bacteria (E. coli was not found in that sample).

    There was no E. coli or Total Coliform found in the well and water storage tanks that supply water to the area, officials said.

    Weird News Photos: Holiday Edition

    The Water Authority said it is flushing the water mains and disinfecting the water in the area. In the meantime, residents are ordered to boil their water before using it for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth, washing dishes, and preparing food. Any ice made after Wednesday should be discarded.

    Coliform and E. coli bacteria indicates that water may be contaminated with human or animal wastes; consumption can cause diarrhea, cramps, nausea, headaches, or other symptoms. Anyone at special health risk who experiences these symptoms should seek medical advice.

    Published at 6:51 PM EDT on Jul 20, 2011 | Updated at 8:57 AM EDT on Jul 21, 2011

Some Clinton residents having water problems

They've narrowed down the source of the leak to an area off of Highway 959. They said during their search they found other cracks in pipes.
CLINTON, LA (WAFB) -

Low or no water pressure at all is a big problem for some East Feliciana Parish residents. They've been on a boil water order since early Saturday morning.

However, some in the Bluff Creek area said they don't even have any water to boil and they want to know what's being done to fix it.

"You don't realize how important the water is until it's gone," said Bluff Creek resident Ryan McLin.

Ryan McLin is one of 150 Clinton residents who have been without water since Friday night, when a water line burst.

He said outages like this are all-too common. "It seems like it happens at inopportune times, and it's real frustrating because you can never get anybody to communicate with you exactly what's going on," he said.

McLin said when he calls the East Feliciana Rural Water System, he is simply told, "they're working on it," but gets few details

Water System board president Richard King said this time there aren't many details to give. He's not sure what's causing the leak. He is asking residents to be patient, since right now, workers are still trying to actually find the leak.

"It's a rural area, and lines run through the woods," King added.

They've narrowed down the source of the leak to an area off of Highway 959. They said during their search they found other cracks in pipes. So as they hunt for the big problem, they are trying to fix the little problems too.

"We gonna find it, we gonna fix it. It's just gonna take some time," said King.

Ryan McLin hopes the fix comes sooner than later. He said going four days  without water is tough with a small child and pets. He's been filling water jugs to keep his dogs hydrated in the heat and staying with family until they fix the water.

"My wife and I and my daughter, we stayed at my sister's house in Central, you know, because they have civilization there," McLin said.

An  East Feliciana Water System worker said once water is turned back on, it may take a while for the pressure to rebuild in the 150 homes affected.

Boil water order issued for Cherry Valley

CHERRY VALLEY, AR (KAIT) – A boil water order has been issued for Cherry Valley.

Mayor Mike Wood says the main water line ruptured earlier today.

Crews have been working since 3:30 to fix it.  He says water has been restored to the west side of town.

At 8 o'clock tomorrow morning they plan to shut down the water supply and try to install a permanent fix.  It should take four hours to make the repairs.

Wood encourages residents to boil drinking water until further notice.

Guard, AF continue support as Minot flood slows
6/28/2011 - MINOT, N.D. (AFNS) -- A press conference held at city hall here June 26 offered a shred of good news for those residents, Airmen and family members impacted by Minot's record-shattering floods during the month of June.


(Media-Newswire.com) - 6/28/2011 - MINOT, N.D. ( AFNS ) -- A press conference held at city hall here June 26 offered a shred of good news for those residents, Airmen and family members impacted by Minot's record-shattering floods during the month of June.

The mayor announced that the Souris River measured at 1561.72 feet late in the evening June 25 and receded to 1561.57 feet as of 3 p.m. June 26.

"We feel the river has probably crested," Minot Mayor Curt Zimbelman cautiously stated.

Officials said that the National Weather Service would not officially pronounce the river as being crested for another few days.

The mayor said that Broadway will remain closed for at least one more week to allow for uninterrupted building of the secondary dike system. Only emergency vehicles will be allowed through.

North Dakota Governor Jack Dalrymple said two disaster recovery centers are scheduled to open June 27, operating between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. One location is the Minot City Auditorium; the second location is the Minot State University Student Center.

Impacted residents needing to register for assistance do not need to visit a center. Displaced persons can register by calling 800-621-3362 or by visiting the website www.disasterassistance.gov. 

Maj. Gen. David Sprynczynatyk, the North Dakota National Guard adjutant general, said he was very happy with the assistance the National Guard has received from the Airmen at Minot Air Force Base.

"We have been working very closely with the air force base," General Sprynczynatyk said. "That unified effort has really paid off. I greatly appreciate the contribution from Minot Air Force Base. We continue to respond to quick reaction force needs, supporting the city and the Army Corps of Engineers. We continue to provide security, traffic control, aerial evacuations and placement of one-ton sandbags. These are all ongoing things."

Minot's boil water order is still in effect and will be until further notice. This boil water order also applies to Minot AFB.

Jason Sorenson, the Minot Water Treatment Plant superintendent, said the breach that possibly caused water contamination has been fixed.

"The plant continues to put out clean water," he said. "Please understand it takes time for something that happened at the plant to work its way out of the system."

Mr. Sorenson reinforced the fact that everyone at the plant is doing the best they can and just wants to make sure they can provide the city and surrounding areas with water for sanitation, at the very least.

For information on how to decontaminate tap water, visit www.fdhu.org

<style id="map_custom_css">
       

/* DO NOT REMOVE OR MODIFY */
/*{'skinName': 'mySkin', 'borderRadius': 5, 'main': 'rgb(255, 217, 102)', 'secondary': 'rgb(68, 68, 68)', 'playerPadding': 0}*/
/* END - DO NOT REMOVE OR MODIFY */
/*++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Copyright (c) 2001-2014. Matteo Bicocchi (Pupunzi);
http://pupunzi.com/mb.components/mb.miniAudioPlayer/demo/skinMaker.html

Skin name: mySkin
borderRadius: 5
background: rgb(255, 217, 102)
icons: rgb(68, 68, 68)
border: rgb(55, 55, 55)
borderLeft: rgb(255, 230, 153)
borderRight: rgb(255, 204, 51)
mute: rgba(68, 68, 68, 0.4)
download: rgba(255, 217, 102, 0.4)
downloadHover: rgb(255, 217, 102)
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++*/

/* Older browser (IE8) - not supporting rgba() */
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span{background-color:#ffd966}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_play{border-left:1px solid #ffd966;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_volume{border-right:1px solid #ffd966;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_volume.mute{color: #444444;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .map_download{color: #444444;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .map_download:hover{color: #444444;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span{color: #444444;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable {border: 1px solid #444444 !important;}

/*++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++*/

.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable{background-color:transparent; border-radius:5px !important;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span{background-color:rgb(255, 217, 102); padding:3px !important; font-size: 20px;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_time{ font-size: 12px !important; width: 50px !important}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_title{ padding:4px !important}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_play{border-left:1px solid rgb(255, 204, 51); border-radius:0 4px 4px 0 !important;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_volume{padding-left:6px !important}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_volume{border-right:1px solid rgb(255, 230, 153); border-radius:4px 0 0 4px !important;}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span.map_volume.mute{color: rgba(68, 68, 68, 0.4);}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .map_download{color: rgba(255, 217, 102, 0.4);}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .map_download:hover{color: rgb(255, 217, 102);}
.mbMiniPlayer.mySkin .playerTable span{color: rgb(68, 68, 68);text-shadow: none!important;}

Stoddard Park beach closed in Holliston due to bacteria levels

Tuesday
Jun 28, 2011 at 12:01 AM Jun 28, 2011 at 10:12 AM

Recent tests at Stoddard Park have shown high levels of bacteria in the water at Stoddard Park and the town has closed the beach to swimmers.

Kendall Hatch/Daily News staff

Recent tests at Stoddard Park have shown high levels of bacteria in the water at Stoddard Park and the town has closed the beach to swimmers.

 

Health Department Director Ann McCobb this afternoon said that testing done yesterday morning and returned today showed bacteria exceeding acceptable levels. Another beach across Lake Winthrop, Pleasure Point, tested within acceptable levels and is still open for swimming, McCobb said.

 

Testing can be conducted again tomorrow morning, McCobb said, and the town will have results about 24 hours after.

 

A variety of factors can affect bacteria levels, such as bird activity in the area or heavy rainfall.

 

"The reason for the high bacteria counts is unknown," said McCobb.

Boil order issued for McHenry Shores Water Co. customers

shaw-push-component

Due to the area power outage disrupting the water system, the McHenry Shores Water Co. is issuing  “boil drinking water only” order.



Although the water is continually monitored and chlorine is added throughout the entire system 24 hours a day, it is suggested by the Environmental Protection Agency that samples of the water be tested by a licensed health lab.



During the testing period, the company issues a “boil drinking water only” notice while awaiting the test results. The company expects the boil order to be lifted in 36 hours.



Residents will be notified if the order is extended. It affects only customers of McHenry Shores Water Co.



For information, call 815-653-2961.

<a class="h6 gray-dark-link text-capitalize block-display air-xxs" href="https://patch.com/florida/sarasota/politics">politics & government</a> <h1>
      Boil Order Issued Near Bee Ridge and School Ave    </h1>
<h2 class="h4">On Tuesday afternoon, Sarasota County began making automated telephone calls to notify residents in the area of the precautionary boil water advisory.</h2> <div class="clearfix summary-additional">
<span class="h6">By <a href="https://patch.com/users/william-mansell">William Mansell, <span class="text-neutral">Patch Staff</span> </a> | <time datetime="2011-07-12 19:59:25">Jul 12, 2011 7:59 pm ET</time> | Updated <time datetime="2011-07-13 06:28:31">Jul 13, 2011 6:28 am ET</time><a class="edit-p soft-hide gray-subtle-link" href="https://my.patch.com/article/1765763/edit" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Moderate Content."><span class="separator"></span> <span aria-hidden="true" class="fal fa-paragraph fa-xs"></span></a></span><div class="flag-fb-like-wrapper air-xs-t"><div class="fb-like" data-action="like" data-href="https://patch.com/florida/sarasota/boil-order-issued-near-bee-ridge-and-school-ave" data-layout="button_count" data-share="true"></div></div> </div>
</div>
</section> <!-- /.block -->
</div>
</header> <!-- /#page-header -->
<div class="row">
<section class="col-md-8">
<a id="main-content"></a>
<div class="region region-content">
<section class="block block-system clearfix" id="block-system-main">
<div class="article-page-default not-posted-today">
<section id="beginning-of-article"></section>

Near Bee Ridge and School Ave”"><span class="fa fa-2x fa-comments"></span><span class="disqus-comment-count p bold visible-lg-block visible-md-block visible-sm-block visible-xs-inline-block" data-disqus-identifier="1765763">0</span></a></div></div>
<div class="content-main-image">
<img alt="Boil Order Issued Near Bee Ridge and School Ave" class="img-responsive center-block" src="https://cdn.patchcdn.com/users/65104/2011/07/T800x600/c02644e5d339645a200a8358a7f3d74e.jpg"/> </div>
<div class="content-body center-block" id="article-wrapper">
<p>A precautionary boil water advisory has been issued because of a water valve leak at the corner of Bee Ridge Road and School Avenue. The water will be turned off before midnight today, July 12. About 185 residents and businesses will be affected. According to the county, the first samples will be pulled Wednesday morning to ensure the drinking water isn't contaminated. </p> <p>On Tuesday afternoon, Sarasota County began making automated telephone calls to notify residents in the area of the precautionary boil water advisory.</p> <p>According to the county, while the it has no reason to believe the drinking water was contaminated, Florida law requires drinking water providers to issue precautionary boil water advisories to customers affected by pressure losses in water mains.</p> <p>While the advisory is in effect, the county advises affected customers to boil all tap water intended for drinking, preparation of food, washing of food utensils, making ice, brushing teeth or for first aid, making sure the water is brought to a rolling boil for one minute. </p> <p>The county will collect a series of samples in the affected area and analyze them to ensure the drinking water wasn't contaminated by potentially harmful bacteria during the service interruption. Customers will be notified by another automated telephone call when the boil water advisory has been canceled, the county said.</p><div id="in-article-boxed-recirc"><div class="text-center air-md"><a category="subscribe" class="btn btn-lg btn-cta-alt pill sans in-article-subscribe l-bold" href="/" trigger="article_button_click">   Subscribe  <span aria-hidden="true" class="fal fa-angle-right fa-lg"></span></a></div></div> </div>
